reinforcements.new_element_id: works-001 (Graduate Instinctual Renunciation Across the Phase Sequence)
reinforcements.existing_element_id: works-002 (Design for the Depleted User at Every Step After the First)
reinforcements.similarity: Both elements address the escalating psychological cost of multi-phase progression. The existing element uses Kahneman's ego depletion framework to prescribe smart defaults, save-and-resume, and decompression moments. The new element uses Freud's instinctual renunciation gradient to prescribe value-delivery preceding every demand. Both identify listing_creation as the peak cost phase and prescribe the same structural remedy: never demand two consecutive things without an intervening reward.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Kahneman evidence: depleted decision-makers default to denial (parole judge study). Freud evidence: 'if the deprivation is not made good economically, one may be certain of producing serious disorders.' The combined insight is that the cost is both cognitive (depletion) and psychological (instinctual sacrifice), and both must be offset at each phase transition. The Freud lens adds the 'why' to the Kahneman 'what': hosts do not just run out of cognitive energy -- they also accumulate felt injustice when the platform takes without giving.

reinforcements.new_element_id: works-002 (Preserve Reversibility to Contain the Revolt Against Civilization)
reinforcements.existing_element_id: behaves-004 (Save-and-Resume: The Platform Remembers Where You Stopped)
reinforcements.similarity: Both prescribe that the host's accumulated investment must be preserved across interruptions. The existing element focuses on the mechanical behavior (auto-save, exact-state resume, progress persistence). The new element adds the psychological framework: reversibility (pause vs. delete) is not just a feature but a fundamental containment mechanism for the host's instinctual need for autonomy. Save-and-resume is the behavioral implementation; pause-as-reversibility is the strategic principle that governs when and why it matters.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: Kahneman's 'commitments to long-term memory or paper.' New evidence: Freud's two types of freedom-seeking (civilized revolt vs. primitive autonomy) and Rod's 'Pause matters more than delete.' The combined insight: save-and-resume (Kahneman) prevents cognitive loss, while pause (Freud) prevents psychological loss. Together, they ensure neither the host's cognitive investment nor their psychological tolerance is wasted.

reinforcements.new_element_id: works-003 (Structure Guest Proposals as Civilizational Compliance Signals)
reinforcements.existing_element_id: communicates-005 (Pre-Packaged Proposal: Present Decisions as Confirmations, Not Constructions)
reinforcements.similarity: Both prescribe that proposals must arrive pre-structured with trust-relevant information prominently displayed, enabling the host to confirm rather than construct. The existing element uses Kahneman's System 1/System 2 distinction (confirmation is effortless, construction is depleting). The new element adds Freud's insight: the structure of the proposal is itself a civilizational compliance signal -- a well-formed proposal demonstrates the guest has submitted to marketplace rules, which reduces the host's instinctual distrust.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: Bryant presents tenants as a pre-packaged deal the host can confirm. New evidence: Freud's 'men are not gentle, friendly creatures' -- the host's instinct distrusts strangers, and proposal structure is the mechanism that converts this distrust into confident assessment. The combined insight: pre-packaging reduces cognitive load (Kahneman) AND instinctual threat (Freud). Both mechanisms serve the same outcome but operate at different psychological levels.

reinforcements.new_element_id: works-004 (Use Repetitive Rituals to Contain Active-Lease Anxiety)
reinforcements.existing_element_id: ds-ui-003 (Stays Manager Weekly Dashboard with Three-Zone Architecture)
reinforcements.similarity: Both address the Stays Manager as the primary mechanism for active-lease management. The existing element prescribes a three-zone architecture (hero card, upcoming stays, historical stays). The new element adds the Freudian rationale: repetitive rituals (arrival confirmation, cleaning photos, micro-review) are civilizational order mechanisms that reduce instinctual anxiety through predictable repetition. The three-zone architecture is the visual container; the ritual cadence is the psychological engine.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: the Stays Manager is the most-visited page for guests (13+ times per lease). New evidence: Freud's 'order is a kind of repetition-compulsion by which doubt and hesitation shall be avoided.' The combined insight: the three-zone architecture must be fixed and predictable (Freud's order) while surfacing the ritual completion signals that contain the host's anxiety about the stranger in their space.

reinforcements.new_element_id: works-005 (Build Host Identity as Civilizational Binding for Retention)
reinforcements.existing_element_id: feels-005 (Forward Momentum at the Close: Every Interaction Should End Looking Ahead)
reinforcements.similarity: Both address the retention problem from an emotional perspective. The existing element prescribes that every interaction close should create forward momentum. The new element adds Freud's specific mechanism: retention fails because of 'narcissism of minor differences' (small grievances outweigh cumulative benefits). The counter-mechanism is host identity -- cumulative earnings, milestones, community membership -- that raises the psychological cost of exit.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: hosts who see forward momentum are more likely to continue. New evidence: Freud's community binding mechanism ('unite men in love towards one another so long as there are some remaining as objects for aggressive manifestations'). The combined insight: forward momentum (behavioral nudge) works at the micro-interaction level, while host identity (psychological infrastructure) works at the macro-journey level. Both serve retention but at different time scales.

reinforcements.new_element_id: works-006 (Make Platform Mediation Feel Like Justice, Not Bureaucracy)
reinforcements.existing_element_id: communicates-003 (Trust Credential Stack: Process Before Promise, Verification Before Claim)
reinforcements.similarity: Both prescribe that the platform's trust mechanisms must be made visible through process evidence, not through bare assertions. The existing element focuses on tenant verification (credit check before guarantee claim). The new element extends this to all platform rules: every constraint must surface its bidirectional protection before being experienced as a restriction. Both follow the same pattern: mechanism before claim, process before promise.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: Bryant's trust sequence (credit check -> pre-authorization -> guarantee). New evidence: Freud's 'first requisite of culture is justice -- the assurance that a law once made will not be broken in favour of any individual.' The combined insight: trust in the marketplace (tenant vetting) and trust in the platform (rule enforcement) follow the same architectural pattern -- show the mechanism, then state the conclusion.

reinforcements.existing_element_id: communicates-001 (Anchor-Then-Advance: Open Every Screen with What the Host Already Knows)
reinforcements.similarity: Both govern the sequencing of information disclosure. The existing element prescribes anchoring in the host's known data before presenting new demands (Kahneman's associative coherence). The new element prescribes that platform value disclosures must precede host information requests at every phase transition (Freud's economic law of renunciation). Both agree on the same structural principle: recognition before demand, known before unknown.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: Andreas describes his units fluently from known information; the platform must mirror this recognition. New evidence: Freud's 'if the deprivation is not made good economically, one may be certain of producing serious disorders.' The combined insight: anchoring in known data (Kahneman) and leading with platform value (Freud) are complementary strategies for the same moment -- the phase transition. The first reduces cognitive friction; the second reduces psychological resistance.

reinforcements.new_element_id: communicates-003 (Stranger Threat Reduction Through Civilizational Compliance Signals)
reinforcements.existing_element_id: communicates-003 (Trust Credential Stack: Process Before Promise, Verification Before Claim)
reinforcements.similarity: Both prescribe that trust evidence must be surfaced before transactional terms. The existing element structures trust as mechanism -> specific instance -> guarantee. The new element structures guest trust signals as safety -> compatibility -> terms -> action. Both agree that the host's willingness to engage with terms depends on first resolving the trust question.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: Andreas requires 'excellent credit on every single tenant' -- a process standard. New evidence: Freud's stranger-threat calculus -- the host assesses whether the guest is a 'possible helper' or an aggression threat. The combined insight: the trust credential stack (existing) is the content; the stranger-threat reduction hierarchy (new) is the information architecture that determines where that content appears on the proposal view.

reinforcements.new_element_id: communicates-004 (Urgency-First Dashboard as Civilizational Order System)
reinforcements.existing_element_id: ds-ui-003 (Stays Manager Weekly Dashboard with Three-Zone Architecture)
reinforcements.similarity: Both prescribe a zoned dashboard architecture. The existing element defines three zones for the guest Stays Manager (hero card, upcoming, historical). The new element defines three tiers for the host dashboard (action required, status updates, background information). Both follow the same principle: urgency/relevance determines position, and the layout must be fixed across visits.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: the guest Stays Manager must surface today's answer first. New evidence: Freud's 'order is a kind of repetition-compulsion' -- the dashboard must be identical every visit so the host saves mental energy. The combined insight: three-zone architecture is validated from both sides of the marketplace (host and guest dashboards), confirming it as a platform-wide design pattern, not a one-off solution.

reinforcements.new_element_id: looks-001 (Warm Containment: Rounded Containers as Civilizational Boundaries)
reinforcements.existing_element_id: looks-001 (Warm Surface Continuity: The First 2 Seconds Must Feel Like the Same Conversation)
reinforcements.similarity: Both prescribe warm visual foundations as the primary trust signal. The existing element uses tokens.json's warm off-white (#f6f4f0) as page background. The new element uses the production style guide's purple-tinted off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)) as container background. Both agree that warmth is the pre-cognitive trust signal that must precede all content evaluation.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: Kahneman's priming research -- warm tones prime approach behavior within 200ms. New evidence: Freud's civilization demands 'beauty, cleanliness and order' -- warm containers signal that this marketplace values beauty. The combined insight: warm visual foundations serve both cognitive ease (Kahneman) and civilizational aesthetic (Freud). The specific color tokens differ (warm neutral vs. purple-tinted), which is a token compliance issue addressed separately.

reinforcements.existing_element_id: looks-002 (Typographic Trust Triad: Serif for Recognition, Sans for Action, Mono for Verification)
reinforcements.similarity: Both prescribe a three-register typographic system mapped to cognitive function. The existing element names them: Serif for Recognition, Sans for Action, Mono for Verification. The new element reframes them through the Freud lens: Reassurance register, Action register, Evidence register. The mapping is nearly identical: serif/reassurance for headlines, sans/action for body, mono/evidence for data.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: taste model prescribes Instrument Serif, Outfit, IBM Plex Mono. New evidence: Freud's civilizational demands (beauty, cleanliness, order) map to the three registers. The combined insight: the typographic triad is now validated by two independent theoretical frameworks (Kahneman's cognitive processing levels and Freud's civilizational function), strengthening the case for strict three-register discipline.

reinforcements.existing_element_id: looks-004 (Agent Identity as Visual Anchor) -- no direct match, but related to looks-007 (Motion as Confirmation, Not Decoration)
reinforcements.similarity: The new element's amber urgency system has partial overlap with the existing status badge system (ds-ui-005, Status Badge System: Color-Coded Glanceability Across All Stays Manager States). Both prescribe color-coded status indicators that communicate state without requiring text reading. The new element adds the Freudian rationale: red triggers aggressive instinctual alarm, while amber provides warm urgency that motivates without threatening.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: status badges use color for glanceability. New evidence: Freud's 'barriers against aggressive instincts' -- the urgency system itself must not trigger aggression. Taste model explicitly prescribes 'amber for warnings/urgency, red only for errors.' The combined insight: the amber-urgency principle is already implicit in the taste model and partially present in the status badge system, but the new element makes it an explicit design rule with token-level enforcement.

reinforcements.existing_element_id: behaves-001 (Instant Acknowledgment on Every Host Input)
reinforcements.similarity: Both prescribe immediate feedback on host actions. The existing element covers all inputs (every keystroke, selection, and button press gets sub-100ms acknowledgment). The new element narrows focus to high-stakes civilizational acts (accept proposal, confirm stay, approve date change) and prescribes optimistic UI specifically -- the success state appears before the server confirms. The new element extends the existing principle to its logical extreme for the highest-value interactions.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: Kahneman's 'immediate acknowledgment prevents the uncertainty gap.' New evidence: Freud's 'if the deprivation is not made good economically, one may be certain of producing serious disorders' -- a spinner after accepting a stranger into your home is a micro-deprivation at the moment of maximum psychological cost. The combined insight: instant acknowledgment (existing) is the baseline; optimistic commit (new) is the advanced implementation for actions where the psychological stakes are highest.

reinforcements.new_element_id: behaves-005 (Wizard Save-and-Resume with Civilizational Progress Preservation)
reinforcements.existing_element_id: behaves-004 (Save-and-Resume: The Platform Remembers Where You Stopped)
reinforcements.similarity: Nearly identical prescriptions. The existing element covers save-and-resume as a general behavioral pattern (auto-save, exact-state resume, progress indicator). The new element adds continuous auto-save within 2 seconds of every keystroke, local storage fallback for connectivity loss, and the completion percentage on the dashboard listing card as a motivational mechanism. The new element is a detailed implementation specification of the existing principle.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: Kahneman's 'commit intermediate results to long-term memory or to paper.' New evidence: Freud's 'each completed wizard step is an instinctual renunciation the host has already performed -- losing that progress forces the host to renounce again.' The combined insight: save-and-resume prevents both cognitive waste (Kahneman) and psychological betrayal (Freud). The new element's specificity (2-second auto-save, local storage fallback) makes the existing principle implementable.

reinforcements.new_element_id: behaves-004 (Ritual Cadence Interaction for Stay Cycle Confirmation)
reinforcements.similarity: Both address the review interaction within the stay cycle. The existing element prescribes emoji-based micro-reviews at checkout. The new element prescribes a full three-beat ritual cadence (arrival signal, departure + cleaning, cycle close with micro-review). The micro-review is one beat of the broader ritual pattern.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: emoji micro-reviews reduce review friction. New evidence: Freud's repetition-compulsion -- the ritual cadence (not just the review) is the anxiety-management mechanism. The combined insight: the micro-review (existing) is necessary but insufficient without the surrounding ritual context (arrival confirmation, cleaning photos) that gives the host ongoing evidence the civilizational order is holding.

reinforcements.existing_element_id: feels-001 (Cognitive Ease as the Foundation of Trust: The First 2 Seconds Set Everything)
reinforcements.similarity: Both address the host's emotional state at first contact. The existing element focuses on cognitive ease (Kahneman) -- the first 2 seconds must pass the System 1 trust gate. The new element focuses on instinctual freedom (Freud) -- the host in discovery has surrendered nothing and must not be asked to. Both agree: discovery must give before it takes.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: Kahneman's cognitive ease triggers feelings of familiarity and truth. New evidence: Freud's pleasure principle -- premature asks violate the host's instinctual freedom. The combined insight: cognitive ease (Kahneman) and instinctual freedom (Freud) are the same state experienced at different psychological levels. The first 2 seconds must satisfy both.

reinforcements.new_element_id: feels-007 (Retrospective Worth: Counteracting the Narcissism of Minor Differences at Retention)
reinforcements.similarity: Both address the emotional design of continuation moments. The existing element prescribes forward momentum at every interaction close. The new element specifically targets the retention moment (lease end) with a cumulative achievement narrative that counteracts Freud's narcissism of minor differences. The new element is the retention-specific application of the existing forward-momentum principle.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: every close should look ahead (Kahneman's associative momentum). New evidence: at retention, looking ahead is insufficient -- the host must first look back and see that the cumulative exchange was net-positive (Freud's exchange of happiness for security). The combined insight: forward momentum works for micro-interactions; for the macro-retention decision, retrospective worth must be established BEFORE forward momentum is offered.

contradictions.conflict: Token palette divergence. The new element references production style guide tokens: --bg-off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)), --protocol-surface (#F7F2FA), --primary-purple (#31135D), --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)). The existing library element and tokens.json use a warm neutral palette: bg (#f6f4f0), accent (#2d5a3d, forest green), ink (#1a1714). The two systems describe fundamentally different visual identities -- purple-tinted premium vs. warm neutral earth tones.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: The production style guide (Agents-data-source/Style-guide.md) is the authoritative source for deployed CSS variables. tokens.json represents an earlier or alternative design system. Prior coherence audits (see MEMORY.md) have flagged this same drift: 'Token drift detected: tokens.json uses warm green accent (#2d5a3d) but production uses purple (#31135D).' The new elements correctly reference the production palette.
contradictions.recommendation: Treat the production style guide (purple palette) as authoritative. Flag tokens.json for update or deprecation. All future elements should reference production CSS variables, not tokens.json values. The new elements are correct; the tokens.json is stale.

contradictions.existing_element_id: looks-005 (Green Trust Badges: Accent Color Reserved Exclusively for Verified and Guaranteed Elements)
contradictions.conflict: Trust badge color assignment. The existing element reserves forest green (#2d5a3d) exclusively for verified and guaranteed elements. The new element assigns deep purple (#31135D) to trust badges (--trust-badge-bg) and uses the purple palette hierarchy for all authority surfaces. Both cannot be simultaneously correct: trust badges are either green or purple.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: The existing element draws from tokens.json's green accent (#2d5a3d). The new element draws from the production style guide's purple palette (#31135D). The production system uses purple for 'important UI elements, header backgrounds' -- which is where trust badges live. The green palette exists in tokens.json but not in production CSS. The new element's purple trust badges align with the deployed product.
contradictions.recommendation: Adopt the new element's purple trust badge assignment. Mark the existing green trust badge element for revision. If green persists anywhere in production (e.g., success states), it should be limited to confirmation/success contexts (checkmarks, completion indicators), not trust/authority contexts.

contradictions.new_element_id: behaves-002 (Cautious Reversible Flows for Instinctual Acts)
contradictions.existing_element_id: behaves-001 (Instant Acknowledgment on Every Host Input)
contradictions.conflict: Timing tension for destructive actions. The existing element prescribes instant acknowledgment (sub-100ms) on every host input, including button presses. The new element prescribes a 5-second cool-down timer for irreversible actions (delete). These are not directly contradictory (the cool-down is a deliberate exception to the instant-acknowledgment rule), but the existing element's 'every input' language could be read as prohibiting the delay.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: The existing element's evidence is based on Kahneman's cognitive ease -- uncertainty gaps trigger negative evaluation. The new element's evidence is based on Freud's two types of freedom-seeking -- impulsive deletion may not reflect the host's settled intention. Both are valid; the resolution is that instant acknowledgment applies to constructive and reversible actions, while graduated friction applies to irreversible actions. The irreversibility of the action determines which principle governs.
contradictions.recommendation: Amend the existing element to explicitly exclude irreversible actions from the instant-acknowledgment pattern. Add a clause: 'For irreversible actions (delete, permanent deactivation), see behaves-002 for graduated friction timing.' This resolves the tension without undermining either principle.

extensions.new_element_id: works-005 (Build Host Identity as Civilizational Binding for Retention)
extensions.gap_filled: Retention has the weakest coverage in the existing library (44 mentions vs. 152 for active_lease per L0 analysis). The existing library addresses retention primarily through forward momentum (feels-005) and save-and-resume (behaves-004), but lacks a strategic retention mechanism. The new element fills this gap with a psychologically grounded retention strategy: host identity, cumulative narrative, community binding, and one-action re-entry.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Retention is consistently identified as the weakest phase across multiple runs. The Freud lens provides the first theoretical framework for WHY retention fails (narcissism of minor differences, civilizational fatigue) and HOW to counter it (identity binding, cumulative evidence, community membership). This element has no precedent in the library and addresses a critical system gap.

extensions.new_element_id: communicates-006 (Cumulative Civilizational Investment Narrative for Retention)
extensions.gap_filled: No existing element prescribes a Hosting Summary surface that aggregates total earnings, stays, ratings, and hosting tenure into a retention-critical display. The existing financial architecture (communicates-002, Single-Sum Financial Display) covers per-transaction pricing but not cumulative hosting value. This element fills the gap between per-transaction financial clarity and lifetime hosting narrative.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. The cumulative narrative directly addresses the narcissism-of-minor-differences problem at retention. The existing library has strong financial display elements for individual transactions but nothing that aggregates across leases into a retention-persuasive summary.

extensions.new_element_id: communicates-002 (Bidirectional Protection Framing for All Platform Rules)
extensions.gap_filled: The existing library has no element that prescribes bidirectional constraint framing. Rule enforcement is addressed indirectly through trust credentials (communicates-003) and agent continuity (communicates-006), but no element specifically addresses the host's experience of platform constraints as one-sided restrictions. This element fills the gap with a systematic framing pattern: every rule surfaces both what it constrains and what it protects, for both parties.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Freud's justice framework ('the first requisite of culture is justice') provides a novel and actionable lens on a problem the existing library has not addressed. The bidirectional framing pattern applies to every confirmation dialog, approval flow, and date change restriction in the platform.

extensions.gap_filled: No existing behavioral element addresses the specific interaction pattern at lease end. The existing library covers save-and-resume (behaves-004) for mid-process interruptions and forward momentum (feels-005) for interaction closings. But the lease-end-to-re-listing transition is neither a mid-process interruption nor a typical interaction close -- it is a major lifecycle decision that requires its own behavioral design. This element fills the gap with a one-action continuation flow that preserves listing data, surfaces cumulative metrics, and frames re-listing as continuation rather than restart.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. The retention re-entry interaction is the single highest-leverage behavioral intervention for host lifetime value, and the existing library has no element covering it.

extensions.gap_filled: The existing library has no element that establishes a formal urgency color hierarchy. The status badge system (ds-ui-005) uses color-coded badges but does not define when red is appropriate vs. amber. The new element fills this gap by establishing amber as the default urgency signal and red as error-only, with specific token assignments and contrast-verified combinations.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. The taste model explicitly prescribes this distinction ('Amber for warnings/urgency, red only for errors'). The new element converts the taste model prescription into a concrete, enforceable design rule.

extensions.new_element_id: behaves-006 (Bidirectional Constraint Acknowledgment at Every Platform Rule Enforcement)
extensions.gap_filled: The existing library has confirmation patterns (behaves-003, Confirm-Not-Construct) but no element that addresses the behavioral interaction at constraint enforcement points. The new element defines the specific three-element surface (protection headline, bidirectional explanation, single primary action) that replaces standard confirmation dialogs. This fills the gap between the existing confirmation-as-endorsement pattern and the new bidirectional-protection information architecture.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium confidence. The interaction pattern is well-specified and theoretically grounded, but implementation complexity is higher than most behavioral elements due to the need for consistent deployment across many enforcement points.

extensions.new_element_id: feels-006 (Civilizational Justice: Making Platform Constraints Feel Like Mutual Protection)
extensions.gap_filled: The existing emotional layer covers trust (feels-001/002), depletion awareness (feels-003/004), warmth (feels-005/006), and forward momentum (feels-005). But no existing element addresses the host's emotional experience of platform constraints -- the feeling of being controlled vs. protected. This element fills the gap with a specific emotional arc: safety as the target emotion, protection-before-constraint as the framing sequence.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Platform constraints are encountered repeatedly throughout the host journey, and the cumulative emotional impact of one-sided constraint framing is identified by Freud as the mechanism of civilizational antagonism. This element provides the emotional design layer that makes the bidirectional information architecture (communicates-002) and behavioral pattern (behaves-006) emotionally effective.

new_tokens_flagged.issue: New semantic token proposed in looks-001. Does not exist in tokens.json or production style guide. Would require creation.
New semantic token proposed in looks-002. Would override the existing green trust badge convention from tokens.json accent (#2d5a3d).
new_tokens_flagged.risk: medium -- requires deliberate decision to deprecate green trust badges

new_tokens_flagged.issue: New semantic token proposed in looks-003. Would facilitate future migration to IBM Plex Mono for data/financial typography.
New semantic tokens proposed in looks-004. Would enforce amber-not-red for routine urgency. Based on existing --signal-warn (#c17a28) and --signal-warn-bg (#fef3e2) from tokens.json.
New semantic token proposed in looks-005. Would enforce consistent spacing between dashboard zones.
New semantic tokens proposed in looks-006. Specific to the Hosting Summary data visualization.
New semantic token proposed in looks-007. Would distinguish constraint/confirmation dialogs from informational surfaces.

token_compliance.recommendation: The primary token compliance concern is the ongoing drift between tokens.json (warm neutral/green palette) and the production style guide (purple palette). All seven new visual elements reference the production purple palette, which is correct for the deployed product. Recommendation: (1) Update tokens.json to align with the production style guide's purple palette, or create a separate production-tokens.json that supersedes it. (2) Approve the seven proposed semantic tokens as they are well-scoped, low-risk, and improve designer intent clarity. (3) Explicitly deprecate the green trust badge convention (accent #2d5a3d for verified elements) in favor of the purple authority hierarchy, or formally reserve green for success/completion states only.

journey_emotion_map.freud_layer: Pre-civilizational freedom. The host has surrendered nothing. The platform must sustain exploratory curiosity without triggering instinctual alarm about what it will demand.

The civilizational cost-benefit analysis begins. The host weighs income (pleasure principle) against loss of privacy (instinctual sacrifice). The platform must make the security tangible enough to justify the anticipated sacrifice.
First act of civilizational submission. The agent relationship mediates the transition from human warmth to digital mechanics. Trust must transfer seamlessly from the call to the platform.
Peak instinctual renunciation. Each wizard step converts private space into public artifact. The host must feel that this sacrifice is honored and compensated at every step.
Sublimation of emotional attachment into economic value. Smart defaults perform the painful calculation on the host's behalf. The host must feel the price honors their space.
The stranger-at-the-door moment. Instinctual distrust must be transformed into informed evaluation through trust evidence. The host must feel like a decision-maker, not a recipient.

Sustained civilizational coexistence. Predictable rituals (arrival, cleaning photos, micro-review) contain the host's recurring anxiety through Freudian order -- 'doubt and hesitation shall be avoided.'

Retrospective evaluation of the civilizational exchange. The cumulative narrative must counteract the narcissism of minor differences. The host must feel that their hosting record is an achievement worth preserving.

arc_conflicts.conflict: The emotional arc prescribes 'pride' at listing_creation, but the existing library's dominant emotion for this phase is 'depletion awareness' (feels-003, Depletion-Aware Pacing). These are not contradictory but they represent different emotional registers: depletion-awareness is about what the platform must accommodate, while pride is about what the host should feel. Both are valid simultaneously -- the platform must design for depletion while targeting pride.
arc_conflicts.resolution: Keep both emotional targets. Depletion-awareness governs the structural design (short steps, smart defaults, save-and-resume). Pride governs the emotional design (acknowledgment at each step, benefit statements, celebration at completion). The Freud lens adds the 'why': the host is performing a dignified sacrifice, not just filling out a form.

arc_conflicts.conflict: The emotional arc prescribes 'calm' at active_lease, while some existing elements prescribe 'vigilance' at this phase (feels related to monitoring guest behavior). The Freud lens clarifies: calm is the target emotion, but the host's natural state is oscillating between comfort and vigilance. The rituals are designed to shift the baseline from vigilance toward calm over repeated cycles.
arc_conflicts.resolution: Calm is the aspirational target; vigilance is the initial reality. The ritual cadence (behaves-004) is the mechanism that moves the host from vigilance to calm over 13+ weekly cycles. Design for both: surface ritual confirmations that address the vigilant host, while creating the predictable rhythm that produces calm in the experienced host.

emotional_arc_check.arc_assessment: The emotional arc is coherent and well-grounded. The Freud lens adds a critical dimension that the existing library's Kahneman-based emotional design did not cover: the host's journey is not just a cognitive processing challenge but a psychological negotiation between instinctual freedom and civilizational participation. The arc correctly identifies that the emotional peak (listing_creation) coincides with the renunciation peak, and that the emotional trough (retention) coincides with the civilizational re-evaluation moment. The key insight is that the emotional arc is not linear (building from low to high) but U-shaped: high engagement at discovery (curiosity), dipping through the renunciation gradient (listing creation), stabilizing at active lease (calm), and requiring active intervention at retention (accomplishment) to prevent the natural decay toward exit. No fundamental arc conflicts exist; the two minor conflicts identified above are resolvable through complementary design strategies.

discovery.note: Discovery has principled coverage through the Freud lens but limited concrete UI specifications. The 'value before the ask' principle is well-established but no new UI element specifically serves the discovery landing experience.

evaluation.note: Evaluation remains thinly covered. The Freud lens reveals the specific psychological transaction (exchange happiness for security) but no element addresses the comparison-to-alternatives moment where the host weighs Split Lease against Craigslist/Airbnb/word-of-mouth.

onboarding.note: Onboarding has good coverage from both the existing library (agent continuity, trust bridge) and the new Freud elements (first civilizational submission, identity verification as protection).

listing_creation.note: Listing creation is the most comprehensively covered phase in this run, consistent with its identification as the peak of the renunciation gradient. The Freud lens adds six new elements here, all addressing the psychological cost of converting private space to public artifact.

pricing.note: Pricing coverage is adequate but relies heavily on the existing library's single-sum financial display (communicates-002). The Freud lens adds the insight that pricing is sublimation -- converting emotional attachment into economic value -- but does not generate a pricing-specific new element.

proposal_mgmt.note: Proposal management has the strongest new coverage in this run, reflecting Freud's central insight about the stranger-at-the-door anxiety. Nine elements address different aspects of transforming instinctual distrust into confident assessment.

active_lease.note: Active lease retains its position as the most covered phase overall (existing library + new elements). The Freud lens adds the ritual cadence framework as the mechanism that converts the existing three-zone dashboard architecture into an anxiety-management system.

elements: looks-005 (ritual cadence extends to lease summary)
retention.note: Retention receives the most significant coverage upgrade in this run -- from 'weakest phase' (44 library mentions) to 'strong' with 8 new elements. The Freud lens provides the first theoretical framework for retention failure (narcissism of minor differences, civilizational fatigue) and a complete design response: cumulative narrative, host identity, one-action continuation, and retrospective worth.

loop_back_recommendations.recommendation: The evaluation phase has thin coverage. No element addresses the specific moment where the host compares Split Lease to alternatives (Craigslist, Airbnb, word-of-mouth). Freud's insight that 'we should be much happier if we were to give it up and go back to primitive conditions' maps directly to this comparison. A future run should produce a works-level element for evaluation that addresses the host's cost-of-civilization calculation: 'What does Split Lease give me that finding someone on my own does not?'

The ongoing drift between tokens.json (warm neutral/green) and the production style guide (purple) must be resolved before any visual element can be implemented with confidence. Recommend a dedicated token harmonization pass that either updates tokens.json to match production or creates a superseding token file. All existing visual elements that reference tokens.json values should be audited for alignment with the production palette.

The pricing phase has no dedicated emotional element. Feels-003 (Dignified Surrender) extends to pricing but does not address the specific emotional challenge: the host must translate the emotional value of their space into a number. A future run with a behavioral economics lens (e.g., Thaler, Ariely) should produce a pricing-specific emotional element that addresses the 'endowment effect' -- hosts overvalue their space because it is theirs, and smart defaults must bridge the gap between subjective valuation and market reality without making the host feel their space is undervalued.

This run uses generic IDs (works-001 through works-006, communicates-001 through communicates-006, etc.) that collide with existing library element IDs. Per MEMORY.md guidance, future runs should prefix IDs with the run timestamp (e.g., ds-ui-1830-works-001). For this run's elements, the library merge step should assign unique IDs before insertion.

loop_back_recommendations.issue: Freud lens adds depth to existing Kahneman elements
loop_back_recommendations.recommendation: The strongest pattern in this coherence audit is that the Freud lens consistently adds a 'why' layer to existing Kahneman-based elements. Kahneman explains what happens cognitively; Freud explains what happens psychologically. Multiple existing elements should be annotated with the Freud-derived insight as a secondary evidence source. Specifically: works-001 (System 1 Trust Gate) gains Freud's 'civilizational alarm at premature demands'; works-002 (Depleted User) gains Freud's 'cumulative instinctual sacrifice'; communicates-005 (Pre-Packaged Proposal) gains Freud's 'stranger-threat calculus'; behaves-001 (Instant Acknowledgment) gains Freud's 'micro-deprivation at the moment of maximum cost.'
